labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Choosing between PQ or PQ/T
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
> guidance on when to use ML-KEM directly versus using it within HPKE would be helpful for protocols that are currently using HPKE

I don't know if we'd resolved on whether there would be a Recommended column in the registry, which is one potentially way of resolving this concern.  Absent that, some discussion of the considerations might be worthwhile.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
@martinthomson - FWIW, I would note that the text you have quoted does not say "PQ vs PQ/T", it says "ML-KEM vs. HPKE", which is honestly kind of nonsensical because they do different things.

I don't think it's the business of this group to opine on when to use PQ vs. PQ/T.  There is not a "Recommended" column in the registries right now, and I don't think there should be.  (Slim if any evidence for efficacy in guiding good choices.)  In any case, that would be an issue for -hpke, not this doc.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Discussed 2025-06-06: Sense of the room was to avoid the controversy.  Will confirm on-list.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Guidance from Deb is that we should have a small comment in the Security Considerations with a high-level note about the differences between pure and hybrid.

comments.author: schanzen
comments.body: I can put my comment from the chat then on the record here as well: I think that the best course of action in order to stay out of the controversy is to only include PQ/T for now. There is really no significant downside to the PQ/T apart from a minor performance hit (and by minor I think negligible tbh). But the PQ-only has security risk attached to it. Putting it into the draft as an "equal" option is putting Internet users at risk atm, because implementors will implement it and provide it. (Understanding the nuanced discussions around PQ-only and PQ/T is difficult to convey even withing the crypto community so I think the task of providing meaningful "guidance" is borderline futile). See also my comment https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/issues/17 which IMO would be another option where no choice needs to be made and both put in. Then, by having suitable categories such as a recommended column, notice how in the hypothetical year 2035 when ML-KEM is broken and no QC is here it will look a lot less bad if the recommended colum sais "discouraged" or something.

issues.title: Finalize PQ/T hybrids
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body: The general framework for referencing PQ/T hybrid KEMs was set up in #5.  Those documents are still stabilizing, so we will need to update this document as they firm up.

issues.title: Add test vectors for some combinations
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body:
RFC 9180 has test vectors for a few combinations of KDF/KEM/AEAD.  It might be nice for this document to include test vectors for combinations including the KEMs and KDFs defined here, at least the combos that are [likely to be adopted by MLS](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-mahy-mls-pq-00.html):

* Hybrid(X25519 + ML-KEM-768) + SHAKE128 + AES-128-GCM
* Hybrid(P256 + ML-KEM-768) + SHAKE128 + AES-128-GCM
* Hybrid(P384 + ML-KEM-1024) + SHAKE256 + AES-256-GCM
* ML-KEM-768 + SHAKE128 + AES-128-GCM
* ML-KEM-1024 + SHAKE256 + AES-256-GCM

(This is presuming that MLS will use the SHA3 version, as opposed to the SHA2 things that are in the draft now.  TBD)

pulls.title: Add support for single-stage KDFs
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
Corresponds to https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/pull/16

Not sure we need all six of these?

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: I guess it makes sense to keep both SHAKE and TurboSHAKE in case FIPS-y people don't like TurboSHAKE?
KT only makes sense for inputs longer than 24kB. Does HPKE ever pass such long inputs to the KDF?

In principle, it's possible via the `info` parameter going into `KeySchedule`.  But it seems quite unlikely, and even then, there's a hard max of 64k, at least according to the current content of https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/pull/16.  Given that, I would probably drop KT.

pulls.title: typos and clarifications
pulls.author: cfm
pulls.body: Just a couple of things spotted while reading through the draft.  :-)

pulls.title: Reflect WG adoption
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: Also fix a minor MD error.

pulls.title: Define HPKE KEMs using PQ/T hybrid KEMs
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
CFRG has two drafts in progress for hybrid KEMs:

* [draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems](https://cfrg.github.io/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems.html) defines general schemes for constructing PQ/T hybrid KEMs from a T group/KEM and a PQ KEM.
* [draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/blob/main/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems.md) defines a few specific instantiations of the general schemes.

(Note that I am referring to the GitHub / editor's copies of these docs for now, since the authors of those docs haven't yet released new drafts reflecting the required changes.  Should be soon.)

This PR just maps the KEM interface from those documents to the HPKE one, and registers KEM IDs for the hybrid KEMs.

Also, as a bit of terminology cleanup, we use "IND-CCA2" to talk about public-key encryption, and "IND-CCA" to talk about KEMs, since this seems to be the standard terminology.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Also: KEM names are likely to change as the bikeshed gets painted, so regard these names as pretty provisional.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Action to take a question about the use of SHA-2 in these KEMs.  Just to confirm that there isn't anyone who is stuck on CNSA 2.0 and so needs a combination with those.

Would this be better?

```suggestion
HNN3:
: P-256 + ML-KEM-768

HNN5:
: P-384 + ML-KEM-1024

HNX:
: X25519 + ML-KEM-768
{: spacing="compact"}
```
With or without `()` on each of these?  `GenerateKeyPair()` sticks out.

pulls.title: Add security considerations about PQ/T hybrid vs. pure PQ
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
As discussed in #17 and at the 2025-06-06 interim, this PR makes a couple of caveats:

* ML-KEM-512 is noted to be "not suitable for general use on the Internet"
* The security considerations get a note describing the difference between hybrid and pure PQ

comments.body:
```suggestion
{:aside}
> Note: While this document defines an HPKE KEM for ML-KEM-512 in the interest
```

Not taking any position on Quynh's feedback on the list.

pulls.title: Clean up the pure ML-KEM section
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
Inspired by [a PR comment](https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/pull/5#pullrequestreview-2898620188) from @martinthomson, this PR cleans up the same `()` notation in the pure ML-KEM KEM definitions.

It also removes the mention of AuthEncap / AuthDecap, since these have been removed from draft-ietf-hpke-hpke.
